trans-unit.source: Create the WebAPI Project
trans-unit.target: Create the WebAPI Project

trans-unit.source: A new ASP.NET WebAPI backend will be created in the sections that follow and it will have three main purposes:
trans-unit.target: A new ASP.NET WebAPI backend will be created in the sections that follow and it will have three main purposes:

trans-unit.source: Authenticating Clients: A message handler will be added later to authenticate client requests and associate the user with the request.
trans-unit.target: Authenticating Clients: A message handler will be added later to authenticate client requests and associate the user with the request.

trans-unit.source: Client Notification Registrations: Later, you will add a controller to handle new registrations for a client device to receive notifications.
trans-unit.target: Client Notification Registrations: Later, you will add a controller to handle new registrations for a client device to receive notifications.

trans-unit.source: The authenticated user name will automatically be added to the registration as a <link><linkText>tag</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The authenticated user name will automatically be added to the registration as a <link><linkText>tag</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Sending Notifications to Clients: Later, you will also add a controller to provide a way for a user to trigger a secure push to devices and clients associated with the tag.
trans-unit.target: Sending Notifications to Clients: Later, you will also add a controller to provide a way for a user to trigger a secure push to devices and clients associated with the tag.

trans-unit.source: The following steps show how to create the new ASP.NET WebAPI backend:
trans-unit.target: The following steps show how to create the new ASP.NET WebAPI backend:

trans-unit.source: Important: Before starting this tutorial, please ensure that you have installed the latest version of the NuGet Package Manager.
trans-unit.target: Important: Before starting this tutorial, please ensure that you have installed the latest version of the NuGet Package Manager.

trans-unit.source: To check, start Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: To check, start Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: From the Tools menu, click Extensions and Updates.
trans-unit.target: From the Tools menu, click Extensions and Updates.

trans-unit.source: Search for NuGet Package Manager for Visual Studio 2013, and make sure you have version 2.8.50313.46 or later.
trans-unit.target: Search for NuGet Package Manager for Visual Studio 2013, and make sure you have version 2.8.50313.46 or later.

trans-unit.source: If not, please uninstall, then reinstall the NuGet Package Manager.
trans-unit.target: If not, please uninstall, then reinstall the NuGet Package Manager.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you have installed the Visual Studio <link><linkText>Azure SDK</linkText><title></title></link> for website deployment.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you have installed the Visual Studio <link><linkText>Azure SDK</linkText><title></title></link> for website deployment.

trans-unit.source: Start Visual Studio or Visual Studio Express.
trans-unit.target: Start Visual Studio or Visual Studio Express.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, click File, then click New, then Project, expand Templates, Visual C#, then click Web and ASP.NET Web Application, type the name AppBackend, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, click File, then click New, then Project, expand Templates, Visual C#, then click Web and ASP.NET Web Application, type the name AppBackend, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: In the New ASP.NET Project dialog, click Web API, then click OK.
trans-unit.target: In the New ASP.NET Project dialog, click Web API, then click OK.

trans-unit.source: In the Configure Azure Site dialog, choose a subscription, region, and database to use for this project.
trans-unit.target: In the Configure Azure Site dialog, choose a subscription, region, and database to use for this project.

trans-unit.source: Enter the password for your account and then click OK to create the project.
trans-unit.target: Enter the password for your account and then click OK to create the project.

trans-unit.source: Authenticating Clients to the WebAPI Backend
trans-unit.target: Authenticating Clients to the WebAPI Backend

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will create a new message handler class named AuthenticationTestHandler for the new backend.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will create a new message handler class named AuthenticationTestHandler for the new backend.

trans-unit.source: This class is derived from <link><linkText>DelegatingHandler</linkText><title></title></link> and added as a message handler so it can process all requests coming into the backend.
trans-unit.target: This class is derived from <link><linkText>DelegatingHandler</linkText><title></title></link> and added as a message handler so it can process all requests coming into the backend.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the AppBackend project, click Add, then click Class.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the AppBackend project, click Add, then click Class.

trans-unit.source: Name the new class AuthenticationTestHandler.cs, and click Add to generate the class.
trans-unit.target: Name the new class AuthenticationTestHandler.cs, and click Add to generate the class.

trans-unit.source: This class will be used to authenticate users using Basic Authentication.
trans-unit.target: This class will be used to authenticate users using Basic Authentication.

trans-unit.source: Note that your app can use any authentication scheme.
trans-unit.target: Note that your app can use any authentication scheme.

trans-unit.source: In AuthenticationTestHandler.cs, add the following using statements:
trans-unit.target: In AuthenticationTestHandler.cs, add the following using statements:

trans-unit.source: In AuthenticationTestHandler.cs, replacing the AuthenticationTestHandler class definition with the following code.
trans-unit.target: In AuthenticationTestHandler.cs, replacing the AuthenticationTestHandler class definition with the following code.

trans-unit.source: This handler will handle all requests that include an Authorization header.
trans-unit.target: This handler will handle all requests that include an Authorization header.

trans-unit.source: If the request uses basic authentication, and the user name string matches the password string, then it will be authorized by the back end.
trans-unit.target: If the request uses basic authentication, and the user name string matches the password string, then it will be authorized by the back end.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, the request will be rejected.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, the request will be rejected.

trans-unit.source: This is not a true authentication and authorization approach.
trans-unit.target: This is not a true authentication and authorization approach.

trans-unit.source: It is just a very simple example for this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: It is just a very simple example for this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: If the request message is authenticated and authorized by the AuthenticationTestHandler, then the basic authentication user will be attached to the current request on the HttpContext.
trans-unit.target: If the request message is authenticated and authorized by the AuthenticationTestHandler, then the basic authentication user will be attached to the current request on the HttpContext.

trans-unit.source: User information in the HttpContext will be used by another controller (RegisterController) to add a <link><linkText>tag</linkText><title></title></link> to the notification registration request.
trans-unit.target: User information in the HttpContext will be used by another controller (RegisterController) to add a <link><linkText>tag</linkText><title></title></link> to the notification registration request.

trans-unit.source: Security Note: The AuthenticationTestHandler class does not provide true authentication.
trans-unit.target: Security Note: The AuthenticationTestHandler class does not provide true authentication.

trans-unit.source: It is used only to mimic basic authentication and is not secure.
trans-unit.target: It is used only to mimic basic authentication and is not secure.

trans-unit.source: You must implement a secure authentication mechanism in your production applications and services.
trans-unit.target: You must implement a secure authentication mechanism in your production applications and services.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code at the end of the Register method in the App_Start/WebApiConfig.cs class to register the message handler:
trans-unit.target: Add the following code at the end of the Register method in the App_Start/WebApiConfig.cs class to register the message handler:

trans-unit.source: Save your changes.
trans-unit.target: Save your changes.

trans-unit.source: Registering for Notifications using the WebAPI Backend
trans-unit.target: Registering for Notifications using the WebAPI Backend

trans-unit.source: In this section, we will add a new controller to the WebAPI backend to handle requests to register a user and device for notifications using the client library for notification hubs, which is the Azure Service Bus client library. The controller will add a user tag for the user that was authenticated and attached to the HttpContext by the AuthenticationTestHandler. The tag will have the string format, "username:".
trans-unit.target: In this section, we will add a new controller to the WebAPI backend to handle requests to register a user and device for notifications using the client library for notification hubs, which is the Azure Service Bus client library. The controller will add a user tag for the user that was authenticated and attached to the HttpContext by the AuthenticationTestHandler. The tag will have the string format, "username:".

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the AppBackend project and then click Manage NuGet Packages.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the AppBackend project and then click Manage NuGet Packages.

trans-unit.source: On the left-hand side, click Online, and search for servicebus in the Search box.
trans-unit.target: On the left-hand side, click Online, and search for servicebus in the Search box.

trans-unit.source: In the results list, click Microsoft Azure Service Bus, and then click Install.
trans-unit.target: In the results list, click Microsoft Azure Service Bus, and then click Install.

trans-unit.source: Complete the installation, then close the NuGet package manager window.
trans-unit.target: Complete the installation, then close the NuGet package manager window.

trans-unit.source: We will now create a new class file that represents the different secure notifications that will be sent.
trans-unit.target: We will now create a new class file that represents the different secure notifications that will be sent.

trans-unit.source: In a complete implementation, the notifications are stored in a database.
trans-unit.target: In a complete implementation, the notifications are stored in a database.

trans-unit.source: For simplicity, this tutorial stores them in memory.
trans-unit.target: For simplicity, this tutorial stores them in memory.

trans-unit.source: In the Solution Explorer, right-click the Models folder, click Add, then click Class.
trans-unit.target: In the Solution Explorer, right-click the Models folder, click Add, then click Class.

trans-unit.source: Name the new class Notifications.cs, then click Add to generate the class.
trans-unit.target: Name the new class Notifications.cs, then click Add to generate the class.

trans-unit.source: In Notifications.cs, add the following using statement at the top of the file:
trans-unit.target: In Notifications.cs, add the following using statement at the top of the file:

trans-unit.source: Replace the Notifications class definition with the following and make sure to replace the two placeholders with the connection string (with full access) for your notification hub, and the hub name (available at Azure Management Portal:
trans-unit.target: Replace the Notifications class definition with the following and make sure to replace the two placeholders with the connection string (with full access) for your notification hub, and the hub name (available at Azure Management Portal:

trans-unit.source: Next we create a new controller, RegisterController.
trans-unit.target: Next we create a new controller, RegisterController.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the Controllers folder, then click Add, then click Controller.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the Controllers folder, then click Add, then click Controller.

trans-unit.source: Click the Web API 2 Controller -- Empty item, and then click Add.
trans-unit.target: Click the Web API 2 Controller -- Empty item, and then click Add.

trans-unit.source: Name the new class RegisterController, and then click Add again to generate the controller.
trans-unit.target: Name the new class RegisterController, and then click Add again to generate the controller.

trans-unit.source: In RegisterController.cs, add the following using statements:
trans-unit.target: In RegisterController.cs, add the following using statements:

trans-unit.source: Add the following code inside the RegisterController class definition.
trans-unit.target: Add the following code inside the RegisterController class definition.

trans-unit.source: Note that in this code, we add a user tag for the user this is attached to the HttpContext.
trans-unit.target: Note that in this code, we add a user tag for the user this is attached to the HttpContext.

trans-unit.source: The user was authenticated and attached to the HttpContext by the message filter we added, AuthenticationTestHandler.
trans-unit.target: The user was authenticated and attached to the HttpContext by the message filter we added, AuthenticationTestHandler.

trans-unit.source: You can also add optional checks to verify that the user has rights to register for the requested tags.
trans-unit.target: You can also add optional checks to verify that the user has rights to register for the requested tags.

trans-unit.source: Save your changes.
trans-unit.target: Save your changes.

trans-unit.source: Sending Notifications from the WebAPI Backend
trans-unit.target: Sending Notifications from the WebAPI Backend

trans-unit.source: In this section you add a new controller that exposes a way for client devices to send a notification based on the username tag using Azure Service Bus client library in the ASP.NET WebAPI backend.
trans-unit.target: In this section you add a new controller that exposes a way for client devices to send a notification based on the username tag using Azure Service Bus client library in the ASP.NET WebAPI backend.

trans-unit.source: Create another new controller named NotificationsController.
trans-unit.target: Create another new controller named NotificationsController.

trans-unit.source: Create it the same way you created the RegisterController in the previous section.
trans-unit.target: Create it the same way you created the RegisterController in the previous section.

trans-unit.source: In NotificationsController.cs, add the following using statements:
trans-unit.target: In NotificationsController.cs, add the following using statements:

trans-unit.source: Add the following method to the NotificationsController class.
trans-unit.target: Add the following method to the NotificationsController class.

trans-unit.source: This code send a notification type based on the Platform Notification Service (PNS) pns parameter.
trans-unit.target: This code send a notification type based on the Platform Notification Service (PNS) pns parameter.

trans-unit.source: The value of to_tag is used to set the username tag on the message.
trans-unit.target: The value of to_tag is used to set the username tag on the message.

trans-unit.source: This tag must match a username tag of an active notification hub registration.
trans-unit.target: This tag must match a username tag of an active notification hub registration.

trans-unit.source: The notification message is pulled from the body of the POST request.
trans-unit.target: The notification message is pulled from the body of the POST request.

trans-unit.source: Press F5 to run the application and to ensure the accuracy of your work so far.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 to run the application and to ensure the accuracy of your work so far.

trans-unit.source: The app should launch a web browser and display the ASP.NET home page.
trans-unit.target: The app should launch a web browser and display the ASP.NET home page.

trans-unit.source: Publish the new WebAPI Backend
trans-unit.target: Publish the new WebAPI Backend

trans-unit.source: Now we will deploy this app to an Azure Website in order to make it accessible from all devices.
trans-unit.target: Now we will deploy this app to an Azure Website in order to make it accessible from all devices.

trans-unit.source: Right-click on the AppBackend project and select Publish.
trans-unit.target: Right-click on the AppBackend project and select Publish.

trans-unit.source: Select Azure Website as your publish target.
trans-unit.target: Select Azure Website as your publish target.

trans-unit.source: Log in with your Azure account and select an existing or new Website.
trans-unit.target: Log in with your Azure account and select an existing or new Website.

trans-unit.source: Make a note of the destination URL property in the Connection tab.
trans-unit.target: Make a note of the destination URL property in the Connection tab.

trans-unit.source: We will refer to this URL as your backend endpoint later in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: We will refer to this URL as your backend endpoint later in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Click Publish.
trans-unit.target: Click Publish.
